channel.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Lothy even if you have it not hardcoded, take XML for example. The only thing you can modify is loot, exp etc, if you were going to add new npc’s to thieve from, you need to edit the hard code anyway.

But even still, thieving code is not supposed to be modified often, i mean you don’t see people modifying the ores you get from mining do you? in fact i’ve never really seen that modified ever. Once it’s set how you like it, it rarely ever needs changing. XML is more friendly to newbies (especially here) as they would have trouble finding out exactly where to modify the variables in the code. But that might be a good thing.

Read full topic

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck
item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

Why are you flaming each other over a piece of code?

I don’t particularly like Hixk however I have to say that his code is somewhat better than Pan^Cakes (Sorry <3) but I’ll be using an XML table to store NPCs when I eventually get around to doing it myself, though it won’t be OS.

Anyway, both of these guys released their code publically, we should either thank them and use it or don’t use it at all. Why does it even matter how long it took you to write a piece of code, I highly doubt either of you did it under half an hour.

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:10, topic:222868”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=292716.msg2357350#msg2357350 date=1217383785]
I’m a fan of hard coding if it’s something that does not need to be changed regularly. There wouldn’t be too much of an efficiency loss in this code depending on how perfect you wanna be.

Though in my case I’d use a switch, I’d handle this in a different class and I’d use a HashMap or Multidimensional array. As this code is only compatible with coins and is not handled for other loot that may be thieved.

But the formula is cool, i was never good at that advanced looking maths so i would leech that.
[/quote]
He blatently ripped the formula and altered it.
Also, I know what you mean by hardcoding, but where NPC’s are concerned it’s a bad idea.
You want a file that isn’t effected by the change in any code, and vice versa.
It’s just a much better way to read from an XML file or something similar.

NPC_NAME/NPC_ID/LEVEL_TO_THIEVE/LOOT_DROPPED[ARRAY_OR_SOMETHING]/LOOT_SUCCESS_RATES

Or something like that, but in XML style. Would allow for easy modification and addition.
It would also allow for different rates for each item.[/quote]

You can make a formula to calculated the rates based on the NPCs combat, but other then that, you’re right.

Read full topic

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

So in other words you ripped the formula and just altered a few values?
Also an XML file is alot more flexible and alot better practice for that kind of work, since you don’t know what NPCs you may add thieving to in the future.
It’s all about structure.

If your adament about using if statements then why don’t you use “else if” since it was built for a fucking reason.
Since your statements never have more than 1 condition, using else will provide efficiency.

Typically when iterating through multiple values you will use a switch, because it’s alot cleaner, and purpose built for that practice. Though it doesn’t provide too much performance advantage on if-else.

I still highly stand by the decision to use XML or some other database style system.
You could write a method to load it in about 5 lines, and a method to parse and check it in about 10 lines, and it will save all the hard coding. The rest would be a more efficient, styled file, allowing for additional NPCs to be added, and for easy modification. It also allows diversity for future use.

Read full topic

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck
item.dc:creator: @HixkPK HixkPK
item.description:
@HixkPK wrote:

if’s are cleaner than switches, and for this purpose are much more effecient. Why make an unnecessary XML + parser when you can hardcode it all which isn’t any more difficult…in fact it seems quicker. The formula is almost identical to demonik’s, not 100% identical though. So what you’re saying to me is that I should be using a switch? Explain to me how that would make things better, nay, faster…If you didn’t read the end of my post it took me 5-10 minutes to code this, and it far surpasses’ Pan^Cake’s shitty coding…He repeatedly blocked the same code into multiple cases when he could have just made 3 int’s as I did, and his formula was a 1/2 chance, AND he only coded 2 NPC’s…but I guess 2 NPC’s suffices when he blocked the same code over and over…

Read full topic

item.title: [RELEASE]RSCDv25 pickpocketing that doesn't suck

Your indenting is horrific.

Why do you hardcode NPCs? Fuck me, if your going to code, use a HashMap or something.
The best way would be to store them somehow, maybe XML?

Also did you write that formula? Since it’s coded incredibly different to the packet handling section?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: July 29, 2008, 05:15:12 pm[/size][hr]Also… where did you get the formulae from? Is it just something you made up? If so… what makes it so good?

And sheesh I didn’t realise until now that you used multiple if statements… I thought you were using case/switch. My god, and you have the indecency to flame someone elses code?
